author: Slidebean
description:
Intel’s CEO is now building Christian AI.

Intel’s CEO, Patrick Gelsinger, just took on a second role, leading a faith tech company called Gloo.
Their goal? Develop AI models aligned with Christian values and a framework called “Flourishing AI” to evaluate systems on religious criteria.
With $110 million in funding and lobbying efforts in Washington, this isn’t a side project, it’s an attempt to embed belief systems into the code shaping our future.
AI ethics just got a theological twist.

👉Hear the full breakdown on The Slidebean Stand-Up; streaming now on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and all major podcast platforms.
title: Intel’s CEO joins a $110M “Christian AI” project

author: Slidebean
description:
We made AI superhuman but it still can’t act human.

AI can do math, code, and write essays but ask it where to find a therapist, and it fails.
We’ve built digital brains we don’t fully understand.
Smarter than us in theory, dumber in empathy.

👉Hear the full breakdown on The Slidebean Stand-Up; streaming now on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and all major podcast platforms.
title: AI’s biggest flaw isn’t technical, it’s human.

author: Slidebean
description:
The AI chip that doesn’t use ones or zeros.

A startup called Extropic is building processors that run on probabilities, not binary logic.
Instead of asking if something is true or false, the chip measures how likely it is to be true.
That shift could make AI up to 100× more energy efficient, cutting data center costs from millions to thousands.
If it scales, this could remove the biggest limit to AI’s growth, energy.
The future of AI might be built on uncertainty.

👉Hear the full breakdown on The Slidebean Stand-Up; streaming now on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and all major podcast platforms.
title: Extropic’s probabilistic chip could redefine AI computing

author: Slidebean
description:
Amazon just cut 14,000 jobs and blamed AI.

Amazon announced one of its biggest layoffs ever: 14,000 corporate employees.
Not warehouse staff, but engineers, managers, and product teams hired during the pandemic.
The company says it’s “shifting toward AI and efficiency,” meaning automation is replacing human roles.
14,000 jobs gone, so Amazon can bet big on software over staff.
Whether it actually works remains to be seen.

👉Hear the full breakdown on The Slidebean Stand-Up; streaming now on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and all major podcast platforms.
title: Amazon’s layoffs show what “AI efficiency” really looks like
